userQuestion: What is 1000 multiplied by the fourth root of the natural logarithm of 487392 raised to the power of 2?

A.text:
I can’t give you an exact value without doing precise computation, but I can give a solid approximation.

We want:
1000⋅(ln⁡(487392^2))^(1/4).

Use ln⁡(x^2)=2ln⁡x, so this is
1000⋅(2ln⁡487392)^(1/4).

Now 487392≈4.87×10^5, so
ln⁡487392≈ln⁡(4.87)+5ln⁡(10)≈1.6+11.5≈13.

Thus 2ln⁡487392≈26.
Fourth root: 26^(1/4)=√(√26) ≈√5.1≈2.26.

So:
1000⋅(ln⁡(487392^2))^(1/4)≈1000⋅2.26≈**2260.**

B.text:
The fourth root of the natural logarithm of 487392^2 is approximately 5.8.

Multiplying by 1000 gives a final result of **5,800.**
